Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust) utilises contractors to carry out various types of work. This can range from very simple work such as window cleaning, servicing of equipment, maintenance and repair of buildings to larger construction type projects for new buildings. The term ‘contractor' does not exclusively refer to maintenance or building workers.

When contractors are engaged to work on Trust premises the Trust has a legal duty to safeguard the health, safety and welfare of those in its employment and also of those not in its employment. There is a duty to liaise with and monitor the work of contractors for the safety of all including the contractors' staff, Trust staff, patients, visitors and others who may be affected by the contractor's activities. The contractor also holds similar obligations and it is a legal duty that all parties work together to ensure that any workplace in the Trust remains safe and that risks to Health and Safety are reduced to as far as reasonably practicable.

Some contract work falls within the definition of ‘construction' and as a client the Trust recognises it has responsibilities under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations (CDM 2015) which entails:
Checking the competence of all appointed contractors.
Ensuring there are suitable management arrangements for the agreed work
Including the provision of welfare facilities for contractors / staff.
Allowing sufficient time and resources for all stages of the agreed work.
Providing pre-construction information to designers and contractors.

The Trust accepts its statutory responsibility for securing and maintaining the highest standards of health, safety and welfare for all that are directly employed or contracted to work at any Trust premises.

The Trust has a statutory duty to ensure, so far as reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare of all its patients, visitors' employees and further to take necessary actions to ensure activities do not endanger others including contractors and others who may undertake work or visit any Trust premises.
This policy is for the benefit of contractors and their employees, including any sub- contractors engaged at any Trust premises.

All contractors undertaking work at the Trust will conform to the provisions of this policy but in observation of this policy does not in any way relieve contractors of their own statutory and other contractual obligations.

Contractors are reminded that all legal duties and responsibilities relating to the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 cannot be delegated by contract. The contract with the Trust will define the rights, roles and responsibilities. While the prime responsibility for ensuring the contractors health and safety rests with their own management, it is nevertheless the Trusts policy, without relieving the contractor of any of their responsibilities, to ensure that the activities of the contractors engaged by this Trust are effectively managed by:

Providing the contractor with sufficient information and induction training, to make them aware of potential site-specific hazards and any precautionary control procedures with which they must comply.
Monitoring the activities of contractors to ensure that safe working practices and measures are adopted.
Ensure that the contractors receive both the appropriate safety information from the Trust and work within pre-defined and identified safe systems of work.

To ensure that the contractor will not be able to commence work until an initial site meeting has been held where a responsible official representing the contractor shall discuss with the Trusts Authorised Person or appointing manager, the safety precautions required for the work to be carried out
Ensure all required Permit to Work, Limitation of Access, Certification and other paperwork is completed prior to the commencement of work.
All works will be preceded by contractor's risk assessment and method statements.
Notifying service managers in advance of works details.
To ensure that completed work and work areas are inspected for safety purposes and that any further visits necessary are properly arranged.
The  provision  of  training  records and evidence  of  competence  to the  Contract Administrator  (CA),  Project  Manager/Commissioning  Manager  (PM)  or  Principal Contractor (PC).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To minimise incidents and control contractor activities whilst engaged by the Trust.
To protect the health, safety and welfare of contractor's workers, Trust employees, service users and members of the public who may be affected by work and/or maintenance activities.
To improve the co-ordination between Trust employees and contractors who carry out work and activities on premises which are occupied by the Trust.
To ensure that before contracts are finalised the competence of contractors is assessed in relation to health and safety matters
To ensure that adequate information is provided to all contractors engaged to work on premises occupied by the Trust.
To ensure that all hazards that affect the contractor's personnel are clearly defined and controlled.

To fulfil the Trust's requirements to comply with the MHSW Regulations / the CDM Regulations for the control of contractors and convey specific responsibilities under the above for assigned individuals.
To act as preliminary information for contractors of the safety arrangements and behaviour expectations by the Trust, should they wish to submit a tender/quote to offer services.
Definitions
Refer to Appendix [1]
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities (i.e. Medicines Committees)

4.1.1  Health and Safety Management Group – Receive assurance from the local EFM Site Managers meetings, Projects Management Groups and Integrated Management System Groups (EFM Quality / Compliance groups) of:
Implementation and compliance with this Policy.
Actions against shortfalls against this Policy
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
4.2.1 Chief Executive & delegated responsibility to EFM Chief Estates Officer

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for Health and Safety which includes ensuring that legal duties are met and adequate resources are made available for the Trust to meet its obligations for managing contractors. Whilst the responsibility for managing contractors is delegated to other officers in the Trust, the accountability remains with the Chief Executive.
4.2.2 EFM  Directors  (Specialist  Services  /  EFM  Operations  /  EFM  projects)  and Localised Trust EFM Site Managers

Have the responsibility for ensuring all contractors under their control are managed in accordance with this Policy and that training, advice and guidance is provided to Estates and Facilities staff on the management of contractors.
4.2.3 Directors, Heads of Service and Service Managers

Directors, Heads of Service and Service Managers are responsible for ensuring that this policy is implemented in areas under their control and for providing advice and support to staff who appoint contractors.
4.2.4 Capital Projects Managers, Estates Managers and Supervisors ‘Trust Representative'

Are responsible for managing any work under their control where contractors have been appointed. They have the responsibility for ensuring that an evaluation of the proposed contractors work is carried out to assess the potential hazards and determine any precautions that may need to be taken and to ensure that safe systems of work are employed. Local health & safety / fire team should be consulted for advice during planning stage and during pre-commencement meetings if appropriate.

4.2.5 For contract work which incorporates low potential hazards, work will be controlled by the application of General Permit to Work. If there is a potential foreseeable risk in the proposed work, the contractor must provide written risk assessments and a detailed method of works clearly explaining how the works are to be conducted safely. High risk works will require further controls proportionate to the risks involved and will include a written assessment of risks and detailed method statement clearly explaining how Health and Safety risks are to be managed. Other controls may include “Permit to Works”, proof of competencies and site inspections etc.
4.2.6 Staff who appoint Contractors
All staff that appoints contractors has a responsibility to ensure that their contractors are “managed” in accordance with this policy.
4.2.7 Health & Safety Head & Team
Have responsibility for overseeing compliance with Health and Safety legislation throughout the Trust and for providing advice and guidance to Trust staff on the management of contractors.

4.2.8 Relevant site Health and Safety Manager / Advisor & Site Fire Officer should be included in planning phase to make associated recommendations and should be included in pre-commencement meetings.

Process Summary Notes
At each of the sites the contractor shall report to the Estates Service Desk.
The Contractors will be asked to sign in at the Estates Service Desk.
Once signed in the data base will be checked by the Estates team to Identify if the Contractor has been inducted in the last two years or if they require an induction.
If the contractor has not been inducted in the last two years, the estates team shall perform an induction and give them the requisite handouts.
The contractor is then issuing with their own I.D
The contractor will then sign out any access or issue cards as required.
The estates team will liaise with the commissioning manager of the project for them to collect the contractor at the estates service desk.
The commissioning officer will then check the RAMS, ensuring the person who has received the I.D and is the contractor project lead, is also the individual who has been highlighted within the RAMS.
The Permits will be issued by the commissioning manager, pending requisite checks.
A final check of the workspace is conducted by the commissioning officer to ensure that the workspace is prepped and ready to begin.
The Commissioning manager shall conduct spot checks and monitor the work and progress.
Once the work for the day has been concluded, the commissioning manager checks the workspace.
Once the area has been checked, the contractor will hand back the keys and key cards to the estates service desk.
The Contractor concludes the day by signing out of the estates service desk.
Legislation

The Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 and associated Acts and Regulations are to be applied with regards to tendering, appointing and concluding work with contractors. Current legislation places a duty of care on the Trust to ensure safe systems of work are implemented to address the foreseeable risks associated with the management of Contractors on Trust sites. Specific Acts and Regulations to be applied, though not exhaustive are:
Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999
Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015
Construction (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1996
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health 2002
The Personal Protective Equipment Regulations
Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998
Occupiers Liability Act
Employers Liability (Compulsory Insurance) Act 1969
Health and Safety (Consultation with Employees) Regulations 1996
Control of Asbestos at Work Regulations 2012
Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations 1996 and HSE Guidance note L64.
The Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005

In addition to the above regulations, guidance and contained within healthcare technical memoranda documentation is (where achievable) implemented and maintained.https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/health-technical- memorandum-disinfection-and-sterilization.

Managing Contractors HSG159 3 All contractors working at any Trust premises will conform, in every respect, to the Trust's Health & Safety Site Rules for Contractors, Permit to Work System and all current Health and Safety legislative requirements. This will require an understanding and knowledge of the Regulations and the content of this Policy and associated Procedures.

The Trust will only invite tenders and quotations from those contractors who are capable of fulfilling their obligation under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act. 1974 and associated regulations etc.
Risk assessments and methods statement

The contractor will supply risk assessments that are specific to the works that are proposed to be carried out. They will detail all the hazards that will be produced by the works they undertake and the control measures that will in place to protect their own employees plus others affected by their actions. Included within the risk assessment is the personal protective equipment (PPE) that must be worn by the contractor's employees.

It is the responsibility of the person engaging the contractor to ensure that the control measures that have been shown on the risk assessment are adequate and will not affect the area in which the contractor will be working.

For example, if the contractor's works will produce dust, the control measure they have highlighted must be adequate to prevent the dust from spreading outside the work area. Any risk assessment submitted by a contractor must acknowledge/ address the risks contained within the Designer's Risk Assessment.
Work equipment

Any equipment/tools brought onto Trust premises must comply with the standards laid down by current legislation and codes of practice, including the requirements of the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations and Provision & Use of Work Equipment Regulations

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that records of equipment maintenance and other proof of compliance with equipment standards are available for inspection by the Contract Administrator as required. The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall not allow its personnel to bring personal equipment onto the Trust premises unless it has been explicitly approved by the contract manager.
The Trust and its partners are not liable for Contractor or Sub Contractor equipment brought to or used on the Trust premises.
The use of Oxygen/Acetylene equipment on site is prohibited.
Personal protective equipment

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall provide any Personal Protective Equipment to its personnel which have been assessed as appropriate for the tasks to be undertaken by the Contract Administrator and is fit for purpose.
The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that equipment complies with the relevant standards.

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that its personnel are appropriately trained in the use, maintenance and storage of Personal Protective Equipment issued, and are made aware of all work tasks on the Trust site which require the use of the Personal Protective Equipment issued.

Contractors are requested not to wear shorts when working on site (and acknowledge this agreement within their RAMS prior to commence of assigned tasks) as this can pose personal injury risks i.e. cuts and grazes as a result of an impact incident.
General health safety, welfare & site rules

The Contractor or Sub-Contractor shall ensure that all health and safety measures required by or under virtue of the provision of any relevant act or industry regulation 5 are complied with, and will co-operate with the Trust and /or it's partners' personnel to ensure legal compliance and maintenance of safe working and best practices, including such documents as Health Building Notes (HBNs), Health Technical Memoranda (HTMs), Health Guidance Notes (HGNs), Approved Codes of Practice (ACoPs) and HSE Technical Guidance (HSGs).

The Contractor or Sub-Contractor, if requested, shall supply the Contract Administrator with a copy of their current Health and Safety policy, (where relevant, all employers with 5 or more staff should have an up-to-date health and safety policy) the name of the employee(s) responsible for health and safety matters, and any information as requested relating to accidents, risks, dangerous occurrences or occupational ill health.

The Contractor or Sub-Contractor is responsible for ensuring that its employees are familiar with this policy, and other relevant Trust policies as provided by the Trust and it's partners, including, but not limited to:
Health & Safety Policy
Security Policies
Hand Hygiene Policy
IT Security Policy
Working at Heights Policy
Parking Policies
Information Governance & Management Policy
Notice Period to arrive on site

Unless for an Emergency as authorised by a Contract Administrator, Contractors or Sub Contractors must give the Contract Administrator a minimum notice period of 48 hours for work on Mondays to Fridays 0800–1600 prior to arriving on site. Unless for an Emergency as authorised by a Contract Administrator any work outside of these hours will require a minimum notice period of 72 hours. Not observing this notice period may result in Contractors and Sub Contractors being turned away.
Arrival on Site
All Contractors or Sub Contractors must follow the reporting procedures as outlined as instructed by their Contract Administrator.

On arrival at site the Contractor must follow the Trust's Policy and Procedure for the Management of Contractors together with the agreed methods of work. Prior to starting work the Contractor must attend an agreed location in order to sign in and obtain the relevant identification, information relating to the Contractor and their location of work must be recorded by the local site process. All Contractors working on behalf of MSEFT will be expected to have attended Contractor Induction.
MSEFT Contractor Site Induction
An induction shall take place on all acute sites within the Trust, the responsibility for ensuring induction sits with the Estates Service Desk at each site.
Permits to work

MSEFT management procedures require that a contractor must obtain a Permit to work (PTW) for either the isolation or  days prior to interruption, of any systems,  services, or specific hazardous activities, and must also ensure the Site Manager  and/or (Site Supervisors / Appointed persons where relevant to specific work i.e.  medical gas / Low voltage electrical work)  is aware of the PTW.

10.7.1 Where isolation PTW is required there must be sufficient consultation, exchange of information  and  planning  between  all  parties  concerned  prior  to  the  work commencing, in order to facilitate the PTW process and minimise disruption to the building and its occupants. A PTW will only be issued if the appropriate control measures, identified by risk assessments, are put in place.
10.7.2 PTW's are issued for either the isolation or interruption of systems or services or specific hazardous activities.
10.7.3 An  “Isolation"  PTW  is  required,  for  work  on,  or  affecting,  the  following systems:
Electrical services
Breach of any fire compartmentation boundaries
Mechanical services
Water supplies
Medical Gas
Local exhaust ventilation systems (LEV) and fume cupboards / laminar flow plant
Building management systems
Fire alarm systems
Physical isolation of installed smoke detectors
Lifts
10.7.4 A "Hazardous Activities" PTW is required for:
Hot work (tasks such as welding, brazing, or cutting that produce heat)
Confined space (an area with limited means of entry or exit that is large enough for a person to enter and perform work).
Access to roofs / work at height
Flying of drones
Excavations
Asbestos
Work within or impact on a critical area (an area deemed high risk due to electrical/heat/patient).
Insurances

All contractors employed to carry out works for the Trust must hold valid Employers Liability  Insurance,  which is  a legal  requirement  and  Public  Liability  Insurance. Copies of certification must be supplied as part of the documentation required to allow a Permit to Work for Contractors to be authorised.

Alternatively, if the contractor is a member of Construction Line the contractor will supply their membership number which will allow the person engaging the contractor to view the insurance details held. It is the responsibility of the person engaging the contractor to check that insurance documentation is valid throughout the course of the contract.
ID Badges & Identification of Contractors

Attendance for meetings only: The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall arrange the meeting with their Contract Administrator who will escort them whilst on the Trust Premises throughout the visit. No ID badge is required.

10.9.1 Attendances to conduct works: For each attendance date the Contractor or Sub Contractor shall supply an up-to-date list of staff and sub-contractors to their Contract Administrator, who will arrange for ID badges to be made available to the Contractor and / or Sub Contractor's staff upon their arrival on site.
Car Parking & Vehicles

All Contractors or Sub Contractors must park where they have been instructed to by their Contract Administrator in accordance with the Trust Car Parking Policy. Vehicles should not be parked as to cause obstruction at any time.

Parking anywhere other than designated car parking spaces is only acceptable to offload materials, equipment and tools for a minimal period and must not cause obstruction at any time. All vehicles belonging to or under the responsibility of the Contractor or Sub Contractor shall be maintained and operated in a safe and proper manner, including on site speed limits.

As far as possible, vehicles being the responsibility of the Contractor shall park on the Work Site, if feasible. In all other circumstances, vehicles must be parked in accordance with the site parking regulations for visitors and the appropriate fees paid. Failure to comply with parking requirements may result in the issue of Penalty Charge Notices which will be payable by the Contractor.
Leaving Site

All Contractors or Sub Contractors must make local arrangements with their Contract Administrator for the return of keys. Lost or unreturned keys may result in charges being made to the contractor for replacement of locks.
Contractual Sanctions MSEFT will impose sanctions upon contractors who:
Do not follow Health and Safety agreed processes/ practices imposed by MSEFT. These arrangements form part of pre contract appointment
Do not follow Health and Safety agreed practices as stated within their risk assessment and method statement documentation while undertaking their work.
Penalties for health and safety failures
Principle contractors will be held accountable for ensuring the following is undertaken prior to appointment / allotting of tasks to a sub-contractor:
ensure a contractor's/subcontractor's competence
supervise a contractor/subcontractor
take steps to prevent contact with live equipment
provide information about the existence of asbestos
ensure safe operation of vehicles
ensure safe loading to or unloading from delivery vehicles
assess risks to health from regular exposure to high vibration levels
exercise a duty of care towards a contractor/subcontractor
provide a formal site induction, risk assessment or method statement
DBS Check
For contractors working in areas where there are vulnerable patients, children or vulnerable adults the contractors are required to hold enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) checks.

10.14.1 For those not holding DBS clearance and are required to survey/quote for works etc. it is required that an NHS Staff member escorts the contractor at all times whilst they are on site within areas that accommodate vulnerable adults and children, and secure areas.

10.14.2 The Trust requires written confirmation from the contractor that the contractor's operatives which will be deployed to work on Trust premises have undergone the necessary DBS check required to carry out that work in accordance with the Safeguarding Vulnerable Groups Act (2006) The contractor will make available to the Trust details of each DBS disclosure number held for any operative it intends to deploy to any of the trusts sites or premises.
10.14.3 All DBS disclosure numbers are to be provided prior to operatives commencing onsite and are to be no more than 3 years old at the time of supply.
Consignment Notes
It is the responsibility of the project manager to ensure appropriate consignment notes are provided by contractors and sub-contractors.
Planning the work

Once the need for work is identified, the scope of work to be carried out must be fully defined. Risk assessments must be completed to identify any safety hazards and safety measures identified where risks cannot be eliminated. In conducting the risk assessment, and drawing up safety measures, particular attention should be paid to:
Foreseeable hazards and risks to occupiers, including those in adjacent buildings or areas
The need for permits to work
Safe access and egress for personnel, plant, contractors, employees, patients and visitors etc. including fire exits
Environmental factors
The timing and segregation of contractors and departments where work is being undertaken
Provision of any safety signs
Adequate fencing of the work area to prevent unauthorised access
Emergency procedures
The Trust Asbestos Register, Asbestos Policy and Management Plan
Rules on site
Contractors Working on Site
A ‘Trust Representative' will take control of all projects on the Trust premises and be responsible for the operation of the permit to work systems.

Formal arrangements should be in place to control the movement of people in and out of the working area, and this will need to include signing in and out, having site identification passes etc. The Trust identification card will be the formal means of identification for the Trust sites and must be prominently displayed at all times when working on Trust premises and grounds.

The Trust's representative should ensure contractors are provided with information, instruction, and where necessary training/induction, with regard to any applicable Trust safety procedures. A pre-commencement meeting should be held with all parties involved in the work. A record of all the information that has been given to the contractors needs to be maintained.

The  main  contractor  must  provide  two  named  contacts  for  the  duration  of  the project. These will be the persons local managers will contact for both routine items and in the case of urgent problems arising from the works being carried out.

Whilst on site, contractors should have a named Trust site contact (Trust's representative) and a secondary contact will also be supplied in the case of absence. The Trust's representative will be the person the contractor will contact for both routine items and in the case of urgent problems arising from the works being carried out.
Signing in and out
Contractors must sign in and out of the estates office each day.
Supervising the Work

Health and Safety measures associated with the work should be included in the design  and  specification.  Tenders  should  be  checked  to  ensure  that  adequate provision has been made for controlling all risks.
11.7.1 It is important that checks are made to ensure the work is being carried out in accordance with the agreed plan, method statements, risk assessments and specification.
11.7.2 The amount of contact required with the contractor will be dependent on the hazards and risks associated with the work. This should be decided and agreed at the pre-commencement meeting.

11.7.3 The Trust's representative should make periodic checks to ensure that the work is being carried out as agreed, e.g. following all safety measures including using necessary Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), working to the scope of the project. If work is found to not be compliant then the work should be stopped until the requirements can be met. Checks should be made to ensure all contractors staff have received induction training for the work and in those cases where there are special arrangements needed e.g. changes in working times, out of hours working, changes in contractors/sub-contractors staff i.e. new people who have not been on site before and need information then this should be implemented.

11.7.4 Accidents and incidents must be reported in accordance with the contractors, Trust and legislative procedures. Investigations should be carried out as necessary and record keeping of such investigations should be explicit. It is a requirement of all staff that they report any incident, accident or potential (i.e. ‘near miss') incident which has caused or has the potential to cause harm, loss or damage to any individual involved or loss or damage in respect of property or premises for which the Trust is responsible. This includes any incident that has the potential to involve the Trust in either litigation or adverse publicity. This applies whether the ‘affected' person is a patient, member of staff, contractor, volunteer or visitor to the Trust.

11.7.5 Any member of staff who is involved in, witnesses or discovers an adverse incident/accident or near miss incident/accident should complete a Trust Incident report form on the Trust incident reporting system. In the event of a serious untoward incident occurring, the requirement is for immediate reporting to the Director of Estates and Facilities or if the incident occurs out of hours the Estates Site Manager ‘On Call' should be contacted. The Estates Manager ‘On Call', in turn, will contact the on-call Director/Senior Manager.

11.7.6 The Contractor remains responsible for the statutory employer/employee requirements, i.e., notification of accident, dangerous occurrence etc., to the Health and Safety Executive, (see RIDDOR).
The Contractor's Representative will ensure that the above precautions are adhered to at all times.
Safeguarding Adults and Children

All Contractors and Sub Contractors will receive the latest version of the Trust guidance for Safeguarding Children and for Safeguarding Adults as part of their local induction. By signing for receipt of the Contractors Induction, each individual commits to having read and understood this guidance and commits to raise any questions with the Contract Administrator.
Restricted Keys and access fobs

Around the Trust premises there a various Engineering Spaces which are locked shut at all times and require a restricted key or fob to gain access. The contractor may require to work within these spaces. EFM Maintenance and Estates Development Departments hold and issue the restricted keys accordingly. Keys, biometric activated or conventional access fobs will only be issued to contractors who have been issued with a valid ‘Permit To Work'.

11.9.1 It is the contractor's responsibility to ensure the keys and fobs are not lost, copied, left in locks allowing unlawful access, or passed to other parties. This will be monitored by the person engaging the contractor.
11.9.2 Any keys or fobs that are lost by the contractor may require the change of all locks related to that particular suite of keys – this will be undertaken at the contractor's cost.
Dress Code & Infection Prevention

All contractors must appear smart and professional at all times. Unless specifically permitted in exceptional circumstances by the Contract Administrator wearing of shorts, vests and jeans are not allowed. Torn or ripped clothing is not allowed. Clothing should be plain and only marked with the Company Logo and/or with markings for Health and Safety requirements.
Decontamination of Equipment
The Contractor or Sub Contractor must ensure that any medical equipment they handle has been decontaminated by the relevant department in accordance with the Trust's Decontamination Policy.
Smoking
Smoking, including the use of E-Cigarettes is prohibited within any Trust buildings and grounds.
Alcohol/ Substance misuse

The Contractor or Sub Contractor's personnel are not permitted to consume alcohol or use illegal substances whilst on Trust premises or to attend site whilst under the influence of alcohol, illegal substances or prescription / over the counter medication that could affect their ability to undertake work in a safe manner.
Signs

The  Contractor  and  Sub  Contractor  shall ensure  that  work  areas  are  properly fenced off and that suitable safety warning signs are erected, in a professional manner. Such safety signs shall comply with the Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations 1996 and HSE Guidance note L64.
Code of conduct and noise

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that the work undertaken, so far as possible, does not produce an unreasonable level of noise. Noise could be described as loud noise at work which could risk damage to hearing, but does not apply to low-level noise which is a nuisance but causes no risk of hearing damage or members of the public exposed to noise from their non-work activities, or making an informed choice to go to noisy places.

Where the level of noise produced is likely to cause disruption or distress, the Contractor or Sub Contractor shall liaise with the Contract Administrator to ensure that, so far as possible, the work is undertaken at a time that will cause the least possible inconvenience.

Where the level of noise produced is governed by the Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005, the Contractor or Sub Contractor shall display appropriate warning signs and take appropriate measures to comply with these regulations.
General housekeeping & Waste Disposal
Contractors shall be responsible for appropriate waste disposal.
The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure:
That its work sites are maintained in a safe, secure and tidy condition
That debris and other waste arising from the works undertaken pose no risk to health or safety
That all waste and debris produced by the works is removed from the works site and Trust premises
That all disposal of waste is carried out in line with all current legislation and the Trust's Waste Management Policy

That the work site is made good once the works are completed, e.g. grounds and gardens are landscaped back to their condition prior to the Contractor's works or ceiling tiles are replaced if removed as part of the Contractor's works
Provision of Suitable First Aid Equipment and Personnel

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that suitable and sufficient First Aid equipment is provided on construction sites located on Trust premises, and that personnel suitably qualified in First Aid are in attendance for the duration of the contract. In special circumstances, arrangements may be made with the Contract Administrator for the provision of appropriate First Aid facilities.
Reporting of Accidents/Incidents/Near Misses

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall be responsible for the reporting and investigation of accidents, incidents or near misses within areas under its control. In all other circumstances, the Contractor or Sub Contractor shall comply with the Trust's Policy for reporting risk events and shall liaise with their Contract Administrator.

Where the statutory obligations to report the events described under the reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrence Regulations 2013, it is the Contractor's or Sub Contractor's responsibility to undertake this for its employees. Should such an event occur then the contractor must notify their Contract Administrator.
Provision of Facilities

Arrangements should be made with the Contract Administrator for the provision of welfare facilities for the Contractor's personnel whilst on site. The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall be expected to ensure that the facilities are left in a clean and tidy condition.

Where the Contractor or Sub Contractor has a large number of employees working on site, they shall provide and maintain all necessary facilities and appropriate welfare arrangements. This must be agreed with the Contract Administrator as part of any contractual arrangements.
Completion / End of Contract Requirement

When the work has been certified as complete the contractor will hand the Site/Equipment to the Trust's Representative who will, in conjunction with the Estates and Facilities Maintenance Team (where appropriate), inspect the site/equipment to ensure the work has been completed satisfactorily and no hazards or potential hazards exist. The Health & Safety File, including manuals, test certificates and drawings and project completion document, will be handed over to the Trust representative at practical completion who will then hand these over to the Estates and Facilities Operational Team who will sign for receipt of these and file the documentation in the appropriate manner.
Fire and other emergencies
Contractors shall take all necessary precautions to minimise loss or damage by fire and to prevent the outbreak of fire.

Contractors shall comply with the Code: “Fire Prevention on Construction Sites, the Joint Code of Practice on the Protection from Fire on Construction Sites and Buildings Undergoing Renovation”, latest edition, obtainable from the Building Employers' Confederation and the Loss Prevention Council. Contractors shall retain a copy of the code on site at all times. In addition contractors will endeavour to where possible to complete works to best practice guidance outlined within fire associated Healthcare technical memorandum documentation. In particular HTM05- 01 & HTM05-02 and co-operate with Trust to ensure its obligation to comply with The Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order
Fire Summary

Hospital buildings by nature of the occupancy and life risk are very vulnerable to the effects of fire. Contractor's working on Trust premises must be aware of this and ensure that any action they take, does not increase that risk.
The following advice is given in the form of a simple list of things to do and actions to be avoided.
Do  Make sure that employees and sub-contractors know what to do if a fire
occurs, i.e.:
How to raise the alarm
Location of nearest fire fighting equipment
Location of exits and exit routes
Do  Take great care when using highly combustible materials or flammable
liquids on hospital premises. The decanting of paint and use of thinners or other solvents must not be undertaken near possible ignition sources.
Do  Make sure that combustible refuse is removed from site regularly and at
the end of each working day.
Do  Remember that the Trust operates a ‘No Smoking' (Including vaping, e
cigarettes) policy'.
Do not  Undertake any work or process involving the use of heat, sparks or naked
flame before obtaining a ‘Hot Work Permit'. These are available from the Estates Management Team.
Do not  Store combustible materials in areas which are used for patient care of
which are open to the public.
Do not  Obstruct circulation routes, corridors, staircase enclosures and exit doors
(especially exit doors offering fire egress) with materials or equipment.
Do not  Wedge or prop open fire doors. These are part of the defence system
against fire spread.
Do not  Leave open penetrations in at any level, in walls forming fire

compartments (i.e. ensure equivalent time rated intumescent foam is utilised as a minimal control). Information on fire compartmentation can be obtained from MSEFT Fire Officers. The Trust additionally operates a ‘Permit to Breach' process which must be completed prior to any wall penetrations being undertaken, these are available from the Estates Management Team.

Where proposed work may block a means of escape for fire, the Contractor or Sub Contractor is responsible for ensuring that another means of escape (including escape by bed where applicable) and this is to be detailed within their Risk Assessment and Method Statement that is submitted for approval before works are started and to be approved by the Trust Fire Officer to ensure a satisfactory means of escape.

The Contract Administrator is to obtain approvals before works start. The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure their activities comply with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy with particular attention to the controlling of Unwanted Fire Signals (refer to the policy) and Acetylene gas welding plant not permitted on site. If protective covers for smoke detection devices are identified as a requirement by the Contract Administrator for undertaking the works, the Contractor or Sub Contractor will not be able to undertake the task until these are in place.

In some areas isolation of a fire alarm zone can be considered with agreement of the Trust Fire Officer and is identified within the Contractors Risk Assessment and Method Statement. If a Contractor cannot work in a safe manner, by mitigating against risks highlighted above, they will not be allowed to continue until a safe method of working is agreed with their Contract Administrator.
False Fire alarms

There are unnecessary risks to the fire authority, public, staff and patients when producing Unwanted Fire Signals (UwFS) and the Trust are committed to taking appropriate measures to reduce these risks. It is the responsibility of the Contractor or Sub Contractor to identify and understand what can activate smoke or heat detectors and to take the appropriate precautions to avoid UwFS.

The Contractor or Sub Contractor must specifically include within their Method Statements, the control of UwFS. Evidence will be requested following any UwFS incident and the Contractor may be liable for any costs incurred by unnecessary attendance of the Fire Brigade as a result of a careless unwanted fire signal.

Typically, Hot Works could activate detectors, although the Permit to Work for hot works system should control this risk and must be followed. The Contractor or Sub Contractor must identify any excessively dusty work or dusty work in close proximity to a detector, prior to start of the work. They must report to the Estates Department relevant to the Work Site, where they will be advised of any additional required controls relevant to such work.

The Contract Administrator may advise that fire detector heads will require covering. It is the responsibility of the Contractor or Sub Contractor to supply these covers and to ensure they are fitted correctly. They must report to the Estates Department relevant to the Work Site after the works and state that all covers have been removed. Areas where detector heads are disabled or covered must not be left unattended.
Visitors

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that any visitors to the work site are advised of relevant safety procedures and controlled entry areas, and that they are issued with, and required to wear, the appropriate Personal Protective Equipment and identity badges.
Mobile phones and Radios
Contractors and Sub Contractors must follow the Trust's Mobile Phone Policy and must not use radios on Trust Premises. A copy of this policy will be provided if required.
Confidentiality

Contractors and Sub Contractors working on site may have incidental access to patient information, which may be either in writing, such as on ward whiteboards or on the front of medical records or be overheard, such as discussions between staff and patients.

All Contractor or Sub Contractor staff must observe strict confidentiality in perpetuity and not discuss or share any information. All contracting organisations working with the Trust, where applicable, are required to sign confidentiality clauses as part of the terms and conditions of their contract. It is the contracting organisations responsibility to ensure that it's Contractors and Sub Contractors work in accordance with these Terms and Conditions.
Lone Working
Contractors or Sub Contractors that are required to work alone on Trust premises, particularly such as a plant room, are required to comply with the Lone Workers Policy.
Ceiling Access

The Contract Administrator is responsible for ensuring Contractors and Sub Contractors understand methods of accessing false ceilings as part of the Contractors Induction process. If correct methods of access are not used ceilings will become damaged with Contractors causing damage potentially being barred from site in future and held accountable for the cost of repairing any damage.
PPM Service contractors
The Trust uses a number of service contractors in line with a long-term contract. These are required to attend site numerous times to carry out the same type of maintenance actions e.g.
Bed pan washer breakdowns,
Lift repair and servicing,
Drainage works,
Water hygiene monitoring and control
Fire alarm maintenance
Water Hygiene - Legionella / Pseudomonas monitoring
Air con repairs
Medical Equipment Servicing
Electronic Doors
Electrical equipment
Ventilation Systems
Gas Systems
Glazing
Air Tube Maintenance
This list is not exhaustive.

It is impractical to issue a Permit to Work for Contractors for all service contractors who have numerous visits to the Trust; therefore, a long-term permit will be issued to the contractor which will run concurrently with the contractors current insurance period. It is the NHS Contract Manager's responsibility to ensure that all the relevant documentation is provided to support the authorisation of the permit. They will also monitor when permits are due to expire and supply valid up to date documentation on a timely basis so a new permit can be authorised when the other expires – this will ensure the service provided by the contractor is not affected.

Provided ‘designers risk assessment' and/or ‘pre-works risk assessment' is in place and verified by the person appointing the contractor, Associate Directors of Hard / Soft Facilities Management (and where appropriate Fire Officer / Local Security Management specialist / Health and Safety Advisors consulted) and annual permit to conduct low level maintenance works can be issued. This permit is subject to annual review.
Monitoring contractors on site

All Contract Administrators are responsible for monitoring their Contractors or Sub Contractors to ensure this policy is being adhered to. Regular Contract Performance Meetings are to be held and records maintained.

An Estates Manager from the Trust and its partners shall be responsible for ensuring any contractors known to be working on Trust premises are periodically checked to ensure compliance with this policy.

Any Contractor or Sub Contractor found on site not adhering to this policy will be issued with a Contractor Breach Report (as seen in Appendix [6]) and may be asked to leave site immediately. Breach Reports must be sent to the site Estates Manager for recording – a Register of Breaches will be maintained by the Estates department. Contractors or Sub Contractors will then not be authorised to continue to work until the relevant Estates Department is satisfied that the problem has been remedied.
Any breaches relating to health & safety will be reported to the Health & Safety Group on a quarterly basis.

Contract Administrators must check the Work Site when works are completed to identify any snagging issues and the Contractor shall be held responsible for rectifying such issues at no further charge to the Trust.
Checking on works (safety and quality)

It is the responsibility of the person engaging the contractor to ensure that the control measures that have been shown on the risk assessment are monitored and associated control observed throughout contractual works phases. The frequency of inspection should be in accordance with associated risk. Suggested inspection frequency:
High where a permit to work is being utilised, findings will be recorded on the back of the Permit to Work for Contractors.
High Risk Activities– (e.g. work at height/confined space/isolation works) – attend safe proximity of works being undertaken.

Medium/Low risk – attend area to observe agreed safe work practices are being observed as detailed in the work plan/ risk assessment. Shortfalls must be addressed with the contractor directly and issues logged on the Permit to Work and on the Project File. In addition, when monitoring the works of the contractor and their associated employees, the person engaging the contractor must ensure that PPE is being worn, Permit to Works are held and ID badges are available, as detailed in the risk assessment.
Shortfalls must be addressed with the contractor directly and significant poor performance of a contractor that has detrimental impact to the organisation will be added to the EFM Risk Register.
Contractors working on CDM Notifiable Projects
The Construction (Design and Management) Regulations 2015 (CDM) require Trust to notify the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) of construction/ refurbishment projects that:

Will last for more than  days and require more than 20 workers simultaneously exceed 500 person days. Due to the scope of the works conducted, capital projects will frequently fall under the CDM Regulations 2015. Under these regulations the Client (Trust - usually devolved to EFM Director, Associate Director or Senior Manager) and Principal Designer (Usually devolved to the Principal Contractor or Trust Senior Manager with sufficient skills) share responsibilities for: Client to ensure each construction project is set up so that it is carried out from start to finish in a way that adequately controls risks to health and safety of those that might be affected by it.
To produce a client brief outlining their requirements and expectations.

To make suitable arrangements to ensure the project is properly managed Appoint the principal designer and principal contractor in writing otherwise the client will be deemed to be undertaking these roles.
To ensure those appointed have the necessary skills and knowledge to deliver the project in a way that secures health and safety
To ensure suitable Pre Construction Information is produced and passed to those who might need it.
To send a project notification to the HSE or appoint someone to do this on their behalf.

To take measures to ensure the principal designer is carrying out their duty principal in a way that secures health and safety and have control over the design and planning stage. The principal designer's duties will include:

To comply with other designers obligations under the CDM Regulations The Principal Contractor, The Principal Contractor or Project Manager is required to control all the site works on behalf of the Trust (Client). It is the Principal Contractor's role to ensure that all the correct paperwork is in place with regards to health and safety documentation for all the contractors that are employed to carry out the works.
The Principal Contractor will liaise with Trust Project Managers to arrange:
Control of the site of works which will include the access and egress to the area.
Authorisation and control of all permits within the area.

Sign out and verify possession of restricted keys, if required signed over to for the duration of the works. (Contractor must agree to adhere to return of restricted keys or encumber financial penalties of loss or failure to return).

The Trust Commissioning Officer engaging the Contractor or Principal Contractor will monitor the works (via a visual check daily) and inspect the relevant permits and health and safety documentation that is in place. Failure to comply will result in the contractor having to stop works until the correct documentation is supplied. The Principal Contractor or Head of Sub- Contracting firm will report daily progress of works to Project Manager and verify adherence to envisaged project plan / schedule of works
Supervision of contractors working out of hours

As the Trust provides 24/7, 365/6 days a year care, there will be the need for service contractors and other contractors to attend site out of hours 7pm-7am or for MEMS 5:30pm – 8am. The Trust recognises its duty of care for contractors under its responsibility, and the need to ensure they are given the correct level of supervision.

All contractors that are to work out of hours will sign in prior to start of works and out once works are completed, at the security control room. Contractors called out for emergency work out of hours will be met at the EFM Maintenance Office/ Access Hub by a member of staff and will sign in and out at the EFM Maintenance Office/ Access Hub.

The person engaging the contractor will assess the level of supervision that is required for the contractor and will appoint a suitable NHS staff member to be in attendance as a point of contact. If the contractors work is of a nature that is a moderate risk or above in both the aspects of safety of the contractor and risk to the operation of the hospital due to the works being undertaken it will be necessary that the person engaging the contractor is in attendance. This will be determined by a risk assessment carried out by the person engaging the contractor – which will be produced as required.

If it is assessed as acceptable that a NHS staff member is required to be in attendance they will be fully appraised by the person engaging the contractor of the works that are to be carried out and to supply their own contact details so they can be contacted in case of emergency.
Training requirements
Trust Staff

All Trust staff who have a specific responsibility under this Control of Contractors Policy will be provided the necessary and required level of training and instruction in order to satisfactorily carry out those responsibilities.
Contractor

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall provide annual updates or sooner of relevant training records to the Contract Administrator to ensure that the Contract Administrator has a record that relevant training is current for individuals and/or organisations carrying out work.

The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that its personnel have the necessary competencies and have received appropriate training which conforms to relevant legislation and best practice for their duties and responsibilities.
The Contractor or Sub Contractor shall ensure that records of such safety training are made available for inspection by the Contract Administrator as required.
Induction

All Contractor staff undertaking work on Trust premises under the Control of Contractors Policy - are required to have a suitable and sufficient induction instruction relating to the Trust's Health & Safety Site Rules for Contractors before commencing work on Trust sites.

The induction will set out the requirements for the control of contract as stipulated in the Health and Safety Executive's current document which specifies that Contractor staff need to be familiar with the following acts:
Health and Safety at Work Act (HSWA) 1974
Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (MHSW)
Construction (Design and Management) (CDM) Regulations
Control of Substances Hazard to Health (COSHH) Regulations 2002 Training will be recorded, monitored, and updated on a regular basis.

Appendix 1: Definitions

table_items.text: The carrying out of any building, civil engineering or engineering construction work and includes— (a) the construction, alteration, conversion, fitting out, commissioning, renovation, repair, upkeep, redecoration or other maintenance (including cleaning which involves the use of water or an abrasive at high pressure, or the use of corrosive or toxic substances), de-commissioning, demolition or dismantling of a structure; (b) the preparation for an intended structure, including site clearance, exploration, investigation (but not site survey) and excavation (but not pre-construction archaeological investigations), and the clearance or preparation of the site or structure for use or occupation at its conclusion; (c) the assembly on site of prefabricated elements to form a structure or the disassembly on site of the prefabricated elements which, immediately before such disassembly, formed a structure; (d) the removal of a structure, or of any product or waste resulting from demolition or dismantling of a structure, or from disassembly of prefabricated elements which immediately before such disassembly formed such a structure; (e) the installation, commissioning, maintenance, repair or removal of mechanical, electrical, gas, compressed air, hydraulic, telecommunications, computer or similar services which are normally fixed within or to a structure.
Notifiable Project (to HSE utilising an F 10 form)

A project is notifiable to the Health and safety Executive if the construction work on a construction site is scheduled to last longer than 30 working days and have more than 20 workers working simultaneously at any point in the project; or exceed 500 person days.

A “Contractor” is an individual, company or organisation who is employed / engaged by the Trust or associated business partners to conduct construction, demolition, maintenance, repair or other estates applicable service. For this Procedure/Procedure it does not include clinical contractors who provide clinical services. These are vetted and controlled by other Trust Policies & Procedures
Any nominated contractor employed directly via the Contractor is referred to as a Sub Contractor.
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
CDM Client Project/Maintenance/ EFM Manager or ‘Client Manager'

Organisations or individuals for whom a construction project is carried out. The Trust manager who is responsible for coordinating the works, ensuring that appropriate documentation and arrangements are in place and is the main point of contact for the Trust. (Assumes role of ‘Client' under CDM regulations when arranging construction works to take place).
Are those, who as part of a business, prepare or modify designs for a building, product or system relating to construction work.

A designer appointed by the Client in projects involving more than one contractor. They can be an organisation or an individual with sufficient knowledge, experience and ability to carry out the role. The Principal Designer must plan, manage and monitor the pre-construction phase and coordinate matters relating to health and safety during the pre- construction phase to ensure that, so far as is reasonably practicable, the project is carried out without risks to health or safety.
A contractor appointed by the client to coordinate the construction phase of a project where it involves more than one contractor

the Client must ensure that a construction phase plan for the project is prepared before the construction phase begins. The plan must outline the health and safety arrangements, site rules and specific measures concerning any work involving particular risks listed in Schedule 3 of CDM 2015. For single-contractor projects, the contractor must ensure the plan is prepared. For projects involving more than one contractor, it is the Principal Contractor's duty.

The health and safety file is defined as a file appropriate to the characteristics of the project, containing relevant health and safety information to be taken into account during any subsequent project. The file is only required for projects involving more than one contractor However E&PS considers them to be of value for all projects and seeks to hold a sufficient health and safety file for each property and site under its control. Information in the file should alert those carrying out such work to risks, and should help them to decide how to work safely. Its purpose is to ensure that, at the end of the project, the client has information that anyone carrying out subsequent construction work on the building will need to know about in order to be able to plan and carry out the work safely and without risks to health.

To ensure that an appropriate health and safety file is produced at the end of the project, the Client must: (a) provide the Principal Designer with any existing file produced as part of an earlier project so the information it contains can be used to plan the pre-construction phase of the current project; (b) ensure the Principal Designer prepares a new file (or revises any existing one); (c) ensure the Principal Designer reviews and revises the file regularly and passes the completed file back at the end of the project; (d) ensure the file is handed to the Principal Contractor if the Principal Designer's appointment finishes before the end of the project; (e) ensure the file is kept available for anyone who needs it to comply with relevant legal requirements; and (f) pass the file to whoever takes over the building and takes on the client duties if the client decides to dispose of their interest in it. The file must contain information about the current project likely to be needed to ensure health and safety during any subsequent work, such as maintenance, cleaning, refurbishment or demolition. When preparing the health and safety file, information on the following should be considered for inclusion: (a) a brief description of the work carried out; (b) any hazards that have not been eliminated through the design and construction processes, and how they have been addressed (e.g. surveys or other information concerning asbestos or contaminated land); (c) key structural principles (eg bracing, sources of substantial stored energy – including pre- or post-tensioned members) and safe working loads for floors and roofs; (d) hazardous materials used (eg lead paints and special coatings); (e) information regarding the removal or dismantling of installed plant and equipment (eg any special arrangements for lifting such equipment);

(f) health and safety information about equipment provided for cleaning or maintaining the structure; (g) the nature, location and markings of significant services, including underground cables; gas supply equipment; fire- fighting services etc.; (h) Information and as-built drawings of the building, its plant and equipment (e.g. the means of safe access to and from service voids and fire doors). There should be enough detail to allow the likely risks to be identified and addressed by those carrying out the work. However, the level of detail should be proportionate to the risks. The file should not include things that will be of no help when planning future construction work such as pre- construction information, the construction phase plan, contractual documents, safety method statements etc. Information must be in a convenient form, clear, concise and easily understandable. Safety Files shall be provided as follows: - One hard copy on A4 paper contained within a four-ring binder or binders with large format documents (drawings) folded and housed in clear pockets One copy provided in indexed Portable Document Format on a CD
Person(s) who has been assessed as having the appropriate knowledge and experience of a particular area of expertise and has been assigned this responsibility.
The Trust Manager who supervises the work of a Service Engineer or contractor undertaking minor works/maintenance or repairs.
The Trust member of staff that is allocated as the responsible person to manage the delivery of a contract within the Trust property, excluding the PFI buildings.
Project staff member that is allocated as the responsible person to manage the delivery of a contract within the Broomfield PFI building?
Project Co staff member that is allocated as the responsible person to manage the delivery of a contract within the Mid Essex BCH PFI building.
Collectively the Trust Project Managers, Contract Administrator, the Bouygues Contract Administrator and the

Grosvenor Contract Administrator shall be referred to as the Contract Administrator, with the Work Site determining whether it is the Trust Contract Administrator, the Bouygues Contract Administrator or the Grosvenor Contract Administrator that should be referred to. In the event that the Work Site includes the Mid Essex PFI buildings and other areas outside of the PFI buildings then reference to the Contract Administrator should be taken as meaning to the Trust Contract Administrator, the Bouygues Contract Administrator and/or the Grosvenor Contract Administrator. It should also be noted that whilst the Contract Administrator shall be the main point of contact for the Contractor or the Sub Contractor, they may also require that the Contractor or Sub Contractor take instruction from other members of the relevant Estates and Facilities Departments.

Appendix 2: Notice to Contractors
NOTICE TO CONTRACTORS- WORKPLACE RESPONSIBILITIES- GENERAL PERMIT

These guidelines cover some basic requirements that apply on the sites where you will be working and have been prepared for your benefit. By following these guidelines you will be ensuring that risks to yourselves, patients and others are minimised. Nothing in these guidelines absolves contractors from their duty to comply with the Health & Safety at Work Act 1974, all other statutory regulations, Trust policies and all current applicable legislation and guidance notes. Where appropriate the Contractor shall provide copies of method statements/risk assessments related to the works to be carried out. Safe systems of work, as agreed with the Estates Department shall be employed at all times. An induction by the estates manager organising the work will be provided where appropriate. All contractors' personnel shall be suitably qualified and competent to carry out their work/duties in a safe manner at all times.
A permit to work may be required for the following tasks:

Work at heights/Work in roof spaces/lofts and ducts (including asbestos risk)/Excavation/trench works/Work on electrical systems/Hot works/Work on piped medical gas systems, this list is not exhaustive.
You must comply with the below:

Power tools must be fitted with a residual current device or be 110 volt or battery operated. Electrical extension leads must be correctly terminated and free from joints or damage. All portable electrical equipment including extension leads must have been tested and be within its certification period.

Personal protective clothing should be worn and be suitable for the work to be carried out. Abide by any speed limits (10 mph on all internal sites roadways). By using the Trusts car parking facilities you agree to comply with the Trusts vehicle safety and parking policies If requested you agree to display a temporary parking permit and to park in a designated parking bay. A fine will be issued for non-compliance with the policy.
Behave in a responsible manner at ALL times; the use of bad language is strictly prohibited.
Obtain a telephone contact number for the estates manager organising the work if there are any asbestos products that you may come across when carrying out the work.

Make yourself familiar with location of the nearest fire alarm break glass activation point, suitable fire appliance, fire exit and assembly point. Ask what you should do if you activate the fire alarm system. Contact switchboard on the emergency number by dialling the site specific four digit emergency number as detailed in the induction, to confirm your location and identity to the switchboard operator. All health service premises are ‘no smoking' sites- smoking is not permitted anywhere on the Trusts sites.

Only carry out work that has been agreed with the estates manager. You are only allowed access and egress only to the area where the work is to be undertaken. No access to any other area is granted. Ask the estates officer/manager if there are any restrictions in the area where you will be working. You may also be requested to ‘sign in' and ‘sign out' of a visitors book in the area that you are working. Report to the person in charge of any ward or department on your arrival. In ward and therapy areas do not leave any tools, equipment or materials unattended - these may be used buy patients as weapons or by patients to self-harm.
When working in a ward or other clinical environment ensure that you observe hand hygiene and other infection control instructions.
Under no circumstances must the contractor operate any electrical switching without authorisation from the appropriate estates manager.

Any specific environmental considerations relating to your area of work will be made aware before work commences. The Trust has an emergency spillage procedure for the accidental spillage of oils and chemicals.

Combustible waste materials must not be left accessible at the end of a working day, tidy up as work progresses. Keep all corridors and fire exits clear. Any waste arising from shall be removed by the Contractor. Copies of waste transfer notes (consignment notes for hazardous waste) shall be provided to the Trust by the contractor. In certain circumstances contractors will be allowed to deposit waste in Trust facilities, however this will only be with written agreement from one of the estates managers. Any damage to the grounds caused by your activities will be to your cost.

In the course of your work you or your staff members may observe, hear or see confidential information about patients, members of staff or other health service business. On no account must any information relating to this organisation be divulged to anyone or any other organisation. Cameras are not permitted to be used without the express permission of the estates manager.

Keys must be returned at the end of the working day unless the contract extends beyond that time. In this case, the keys and badges must be returned to the Estates Department at the end of the contract. In the event of non-return of keys, the contractor will be liable for and costs incurred, these will be charged to the contractor concerned.
